newsitem.title: LEBANON: End of U.S. ban raises Lebanon airline's hopes.
newsitem.headline: End of U.S. ban raises Lebanon airline's hopes.

text.p: National carrier Middle East Airlines on Wednesday said it hoped the U.S. decision to end a ban on American citizens travelling to Lebanon would allow it to resume direct flights to the United States.

"We hope that this move will quickly lead to other practical moves that will make it easier to resume direct flights to the United States which ended in 1985," MEA Chairman Khaled Salam said in a press statement.
U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright on Wednesday announced she would not extend the travel ban in force since 1985.

The ban was imposed after the 1985 hijacking of a TWA airliner to Beirut during which a U.S. passenger was killed amid a spate of kidnappings of foreigners -- mainly Americans -- by Moslem fundamentalists opposed to U.S. policy in the region.

Lebanon had long campaigned for a lifting of the travel ban, which it said was no longer justified with the release of the last kidnap victims more than five years ago and the ending of the 15-year civil war in 1990.
Salam has said the company was expected to lose $20 million in 1997 and break even in 1998. It lost $50 million in 1996.
